data.name: Basic HTTP Response Class
data.description:
# Basic HTTP Response Class

Let's build a `Response` class to encapsulate HTTP response information and logic for our fictional microframework Kwipper.

You will have to implement the predefined methods in order to pass the tests. Your class will be instantiated with a mock `Request` object.

**The example tests are the specifications you need to follow to implement the Response class and pass this kata.**


The test environment will be preloaded with:

```ruby
require "securerandom"

# Test mocks
User = Struct.new "User", :id, :name
Session = Struct.new "Session", :user_id, :session_id
Request = Struct.new "Request", :cookies

# Default values
SESSION_COOKIE_NAME = "kwipper_session"

response_factory = -> (attributes = {}) do
  Response.new Request.new(attributes.fetch(:request_cookies, {}))
end
```

For the `set_status` and `to_http_response` methods to work, you have to create a `:symbol => [code, message]` hash so you can easily set both the http code and message with the given symbol.

For example:

```ruby
HTTP_STATUSES = { created: [201, "Created"] }
code, message = HTTP_STATUSES[:created]
# code == 201
# message == "Created"
```

The tests expect you to support the following HTTP statuses:

 - :ok
 - :created
 - :not_found
 - :unauthorized
 
The messages should be the standard HTTP status message as given by [this wikipedia article](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_HTTP_status_codes).

Everything else you need to know can be derived from the test cases.

This is a big kata but, you can do it. Believe in your self. [Rock and roll!](http://stream1.gifsoup.com/view6/2767947/thumbs-up-for-rock-and-roll-o.gif)
